titleStmt.title: What shall the great poet
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Based on the handwriting, Edward Grier posits that this manuscript dates to the 1850s (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 4:1560). It may have contributed to a passage in the prose preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass in which Whitman writes that the "swarms of the polished deprecating and reflectors and the polite float off and leave no remembrance" (xii).

note.p: This note possibly contributed to a passage in the prose preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass in which Whitman writes that the "swarms of the polished deprecating and reflectors and the polite float off and leave no remembrance" (1855, p. xii).

bibl.title: Suggestions for Poems

body.p: What shall the great poet be then? Shall he be a timid apologetic person, deprecating himself, guarding off the effects he won
